body: LEAD: AS winter moves into its final month this weekend, New Yorkers may already be dreaming of spring. Nevertheless, many cold-weather pleasures still await the intrepid outdoor explorer. title: A GUIDE TO SLIDING, GLIDING AND RIDING ON A WINTRY DAY

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: LEAD: The Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has told his 850 priests that groups that condone homosexual activity will no longer be allowed to use churches, hospitals or colleges for meetings or religious services. The ban applies to the two boroughs in the diocese, Brooklyn and Queens. The Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of
title: BROOKLYN BISHOP LIMITS CHURCH USE BY HOMOSEXUALS

body: LEAD: CLEM LABINE and Patricia Poore have two golden rules for restoring old houses. CLEM LABINE and Patricia Poore have two golden rules for restoring old houses. title: THE OLD-HOUSE JOURNAL COMES OF AGE

body: LEAD: IF someone could ask for more trees on East Ninth Street, Joanne Schultz and some friends figured, they could also ask Community Board 3 in Manhattan to support a negotiated peace in Nicaragua. title: NICARAGUA IS AIDED BY SISTER CITY PROJECTS

body: LEAD: WHEN Bill Dillard was not on the road, singing and acting in musicals or playing his trumpet with Louis Armstrong, he lived in rental apartments in Harlem. title: CO-OP HUNTING IN THE OUTER BOROUGHS

body: LEAD: Sixty-six students at William Alexander Junior High School in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn are spending two class periods a week in stores along Brooklyn's Fifth Avenue. title: A TEACHER SHOPS FOR SCIENCE
